thread.title: Texas & Neighbors: Summer events include food and art for everyone
thread.title_full: Texas & Neighbors: Summer events include food and art for everyone | Dallas Morning News

author: dallasnews
title: Texas & Neighbors: Summer events include food and art for everyone
text:
NEW ORLEANS
Don’t miss Crescent City artists at outdoor market When you’re planning a trip to New Orleans, mark your calendar for the last Saturday of the month and save time for a visit to the Arts Market of New Orleans’ open-air marketplace. Expect about 80 New Orleans and Gulf Coast artists selling paintings, photography, prints, ceramics, glass pieces, jewelry, handmade clothing and soap.
The market has live entertainment by Louisiana musicians, crafts activities at the Kids Tent and food made by local vendors.
The Arts Market, which is from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. each month, is in Palmer Park, bordered by South Carrollton Avenue and South Claiborne Avenue, at the end of the St. Charles Streetcar line.
Contact: artsneworleans.org , pull down Arts Market of New Orleans under the People tab.
LUCKENBACH
Hill Country fest features local wines, food truck fare Live music, local wines and more food than one can eat in a day will be available at the second annual Hill Country Food Truck Festival on Aug. 1 in Luckenbach, just outside Fredericksburg.
The event will host more than a dozen food trucks, including Rickshaw Stop, Slider Provider, Cheesy Jane’s, Wheelie Gourmet, Teka Molina, Come and Get It Chuck Wagon, Stout’s Pizza, Saweet Cupcakes and others.
Nine Hill Country wineries, including Lost Draw Cellars, Becker Vineyards and Kerrville Hills Winery, will sell drinks by the bottle or glass.
The Americana live music schedule includes Ben Beckendorf Band, Tessy Lou and the Shotgun Stars, Adam and Chris Carroll, Midland and Paul Cauthen.
Proceeds will benefit the nonprofit Texas Center for Wine and Culinary Arts, a planned 30,000-square-foot facility that will be in downtown Fredericksburg. Other event organizers include Luckenbach Texas, the San Antonio Food Truck Association, the Texas Hill Country Wineries and the Fredericksburg Convention & Visitor Bureau.
Tickets, which are available at luckenbachtexas.com, are $15 per person for adults. Children 12 and younger are free. Fredericksburg Inn and Suites will offer limited discounted rates for attendees. Call 830-997-0202 or 1-800-446-0202 and use the code “food truck festival” for the group rate.
Contact: 412 Luckenbach Town Loop, Fredericksburg, 830-997-3224; visitfredericksburgtx.com
AUSTIN Chef celebrates Thai street food at pop-up events Hotel San Jose and Jo’s Coffee will host Pranom Pop-Up, a Thai street food concept by chef Dream Kasestad. The chef will prepare a rotating menu of Thai late-night street dishes to be accompanied by a suggested cocktail, iced coffee or tea.
The event is 8 to 11 p.m. Thursdays at Hotel San Jose and 6 to 9 p.m. Saturdays at Jo’s Coffee through September.
Contact: Hotel San Jose, 1316 S. Congress Ave., Austin, 512-852-2360; sanjosehotel.com/lounge ; Jo’s Coffee, 1300 S. Congress Ave., Austin, 512-444-3800; joscoffee.com
WAGONER, OKLA.
Renovations completed at 250-acre resort The Canebrake, an eco-friendly luxury resort in Wagoner, Okla., is ready to show off its $2 million renovations.
Attention to the environment has earned the property the designation of being the first gold-level eco-certified restaurant and lodging facility in Oklahoma. The renovations include many earth-friendly choices, from salvaging and reusing materials from the property’s original structure to using LED lighting and low-energy appliances.
The expansion includes four spa treatment rooms; eucalyptus steam rooms and infrared saunas; a gym and fitness studio; and an 1,800-square-foot pool with poolside grill and bar. The location also includes a FEMA-approved storm shelter.
Guests can wander the northeast Oklahoma resort’s winding trails or stay on the property to enjoy live music or a class in the yoga barn.
Contact: 33241 E. 732nd Road, Wagoner, Okla., 918-485-1810; thecanebrake.com
